title: Stock Market Today: Dow Claws Out Gains as U.K. Begins Vaccine Rollout
text: The fight against COVID-19 reached a new milestone on Tuesday, helping the markets finish with slight gains and pushing a few indices to new highs. The United Kingdom began administering the first doses of a coronavirus vaccine from Pfizer (PFE, +3.2%) and BioNTech (BNTX, +1.9%) that received emergency-use authorization there last week (a similar U.S. clearance is expected in days).

title: We would remain invested and positive in the markets: Synovus CIO Nobles
text: Robert Nobles, Synovus CIO, says he would not be trimming back at this time as they expect 4-5 percent growth in the fourth quarter. He says he sees more growth in the second and third quarter in 2021.

title: S&P 500 Index: Resilient Bulls Keeps Trends Positive
text: Monday's stock market pullback saw the S&P 500 Index find support and stabilize above last Friday's lows. Until the S&P 500 makes multi-day lows or breaks its current short-term trend line (higher) from late October further gains look possible into mid-December.

title: The Dow Rose Only 104 Points Because Stocks Have Run Hot Lately
text: Some on Wall Street say the market is “consolidating,” or failing to move much in one direction or the other while investors gauge progress on earnings and economic growth.

title: API reports a more than 1 million-barrel weekly climb in U.S. crude supplies, sources say
text: The American Petroleum Institute reported late Tuesday that U.S. crude supplies rose by 1.1 million barrels for the week ended Dec. 4, according to sources. The data also reportedly showed gasoline stockpiles up by 6.4 million barrels, while distillate inventories climbed by 2.3 million barrels.

title: Is a stimulus deal necessary for economic recovery?
text: BNY Mellon Investments chief strategist Alicia Levine and ADP chief economist Nela Richardson discuss a potential stimulus deal with FOX Business' Charles Payne. Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: This will be the most highly anticipated drug rollout in history: Jefferies health-care strategist
text: Jared Holz, health care equity strategist at Jefferies says it seems reasonable to rollout Covid-19 vaccines by April and May 2021. He joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the Covid-19 vaccine distribution plan.

title: Most institutional investors say the market is underestimating COVID-19's long-term impact on the economy, a Natixis survey finds
text: Eight in 10 institutional investors say the market is underestimating the COVID-19 pandemic's long-term impact on the economy, and 79% don't expect a full economic recovery until 2022 or 2023. That's according to the recently released Institutional Investor Outlook survey from Natixis Investment Managers. The firm surveyed 500 institutional investors who collectively manage more than $13 trillion in assets in 29 countries.  The survey results reveal a stark contrast to more bullish calls on the economy, like Wharton's Jeremy Siegel who says the economy and stock market will be stronger than expected in 2021.

title: US Stocks Close Higher Tuesday
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 30,173.88 on Tuesday with a gain of 104.09 points or 0.35%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,702.25 for a gain of 10.29 points or 0.28%.

title: S&P 500, Dow close at record highs amid Pfizer vaccine rollout and stimulus progress
text: US equities retraced early losses and rallied to fresh record highs on Tuesday as Congress made mild progress in stimulus talks and investors cheered the first COVID-19 vaccinations. The S&P 500, Nasdaq composite, and Dow Jones industrial average all closed at all-time peaks. Senate Majority Mitch McConnell inched closer to reaching a compromise with Democrats in Congress over a new stimulus deal. After proposing his own measure on Monday, the senator said that both parties will need to set aside some differences to pass a relief package.

title: S&P 500, Nasdaq close at records as stocks post modest gains
text: Stocks ended slightly higher Tuesday, enough to push the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite to record finishes as investors tracked progress toward another round of aid spending and Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE began the rollout of their COVID-19 vaccine in the U.K. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended with a gain of around 105 points, or 0.3%, near 30,174. The S&P 500 logged a rise of around 10 points, or 0.3%, to close at a record 3,702, while the Nasdaq Composite built on Monday's record finish by rising around 63 points or 0.5%, to finish near 12,583.

text: Russ Koesterich, BlackRock Global Allocation Fund portfolio manager, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss his outlook for 2021 in terms of stocks and the economy.

title: Goldman Sachs increases its 4th-quarter GDP-growth estimate to 5% on promise of mass vaccinations
text: Forecasters are extrapolating too much from past cycles as they best guess what economic growth will be in the coming quarters, according to Goldman Sach's Chief Economist Jan Hatzius. That's one reason why Hatzius sees global economic growth surprising to the upside in the fourth quarter and in 2021, according to a Tuesday note.

title: Investors expecting 'constant bailout' from the Fed may be disappointed in 2021, BofA's top stock strategist says
text: The stock market's dependency on fiscal and monetary support may be challenged in 2021, according to Bank of America's Savita Subramanian. The head of US equity and quantitative Strategy told CNBC on Tuesday that it's unlikely the US will see a "really strong" fiscal stimulus package passed next year, particularly because of gridlock in Washington. Investors anticipating a strong boost to markets from the aid package and subsequent fiscal support in the years to come may be disappointed, she added.  "The market is expecting this constant bailout from fiscal, from the Fed," Subramanian said. "And it's going to be harder to get anything done in Washington over the next few months and over the next couple of years if we have continued gridlock."

title: Market Extra: What will 2021 bring for ETFs?
text: 2020 proved that it's hard to make predictions, especially about markets. Still, some trends almost are certain to transpire next year in the ETF industry and for investors in the products.

title: Investors are optimistic about next year, but all of the good news might already be priced in
text: If you had said at the start of 2020 that the economy would shut down, the unemployment rate would skyrocket and earnings would plunge due to a highly contagious and lethal virus and we'd still end the year with stocks near all-time highs, people would think you were crazy.

title: S&P 500 Risk Off? Watch the Put-Call Ratio and US Dollar

title: Stocks could stumble in early 2021 as investor sentiment surges past market fundamentals, Goldman Sachs says
text: Unusually optimistic investor sentiment endangers the stock market's near-record levels heading into the new year, Goldman Sachs strategists said Monday. Positioning in stocks is at "extremely stretched" levels as prices rally further beyond equities' fundamentals, the team led by Arjun Menon said in a note to clients. The bank's Sentiment Indicator — which tracks stock positioning among retail, institutional, and foreign investors — landed two standard deviations above average on Friday, representing a 98th percentile reading since 2009. The gauge last hit that level in September 2019, months before the coronavirus ended the US's longest bull market in history.

title: Are Bullish Investors Right to Factor Vaccine Into Market Prices?
text: Vaccine hopes continue to spur investor confidence that an economic rebound is in swing and could get a boost in the months ahead. Whether this happens are not is the trillion(s) dollar question.

title: Record High S&P 500 Ignites Unhealthy Retail Investor Interest
text: Positioning in U.S. stocks is flashing a short-term warning sign as the market hits record highs and shrugs off rising Covid cases, lockdowns and weaker economic data. Horizon Investments is noticing rising retail investor demand for call options.

title: Stock Buybacks Have Fallen Off a Cliff. Why They're Set to Make a Comeback.
text: Companies are beginning to buy back their stock again as confidence in the economic recovery increases. That's good news for the market.

title: Keep Selling the Dollar Says Englander
text: Dec.08 -- Stephen Englander, global head of G10 FX research at Standard Chartered, sees emerging markets driving dollar weakness as he examines the currency's selloff. He speaks on "Bloomberg Markets: European Close.
